paper.title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade

core_question: Can intratumoral mRNA vaccination sensitize tumors to immune checkpoint blockade by improving antigen presentation and immune activation?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse efficacy cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Preclinical arm across multiple murine tumor models combining intratumoral mRNA vaccine with anti-PD-L1, pooled across repeat experiments.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse control cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Matched control setting including vaccine-only, ICI-only, and vehicle groups across the murine experiments.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Retrospective metastatic cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Retrospective cohort of metastatic patients receiving ICI treatment, stratified by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Vaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Subgroup of the retrospective cohort with prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Unvaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Subgroup of the retrospective cohort without prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination.

major_limitations: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized, so residual confounding is likely.
Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients.
Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit direct causal interpretation.
Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.
Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all settings.
